Exploring Bhaktapur Square

Visiting Nepal for the first time, I made sure to include **Bhaktapur Durbar Square** on my travel list. Known for its **rich heritage and historical significance**, this iconic site in the Kathmandu Valley truly lived up to its reputation as one of Nepal’s must-visit destinations.

From the moment I entered the square, I was captivated by its **wonderful charm**. The intricate architecture of the ancient temples, palaces, and courtyards speaks volumes about Nepal’s glorious past. The atmosphere was **lively and bustling with tourists** from around the globe, all eager to soak in the beauty of this UNESCO World Heritage Site.

One of the highlights of my visit was trying my hand at **pottery making**. Bhaktapur is famous for its traditional pottery, and joining a local artisan at his wheel was an unforgettable experience. Though my creation was far from perfect, the joy of crafting something with my own hands made it all worthwhile.

Another treat that I couldn’t resist was the famous **Juju Dhau**, or “King of Yogurts.” This creamy, sweet delight lived up to its name and instantly became one of my favorite Nepali treats. It’s a must-try for anyone visiting Bhaktapur!

I also took my time to explore every **nook and cranny of the narrow streets**, which were filled with local shops, art galleries, and handicrafts. One of my best finds was a beautifully crafted **Kashmiri shawl**, a perfect souvenir to remember my trip by.

Bhaktapur Square isn’t just a historical site; it’s a living, breathing cultural hub. The combination of ancient heritage, vibrant markets, and friendly locals creates an experience that’s truly unique. If you’re visiting Kathmandu, don’t miss this **wonderful place**. It’s a treasure trove of history and culture that will leave you with memories to cherish forever!

Badrinath, located in Uttarakhand, is one of the most sacred pilgrimage sites for Hindus and part of the Char Dham Yatra. Here’s an honest review:

Badrinath is dedicated to Lord Vishnu and offers a deeply spiritual experience. The temple's serene location, surrounded by the majestic Himalayas, enhances its divine aura. Devotees often describe the darshan as peaceful and fulfilling.

- Connectivity:Roads are well-maintained but can be challenging due to steep terrain.

Overall Experience
Badrinath offers a combination of spiritual solace and natural splendor. Despite minor challenges, the divine atmosphere and scenic charm make it a must-visit for devotees and travelers alike.

There is no historical record about the temple, but there is a mention of the presiding deity Badrinath in Vedic scriptures (c. 1750–500 BCE).[6] According to some accounts, the shrine was worshipped in some form in the Vedic period. Later, during Ashoka's reign, because of the spread of Buddhism, this shrine might have been converted into a Buddhist shrine. The temple was a Buddhist shrine till the 8th century and Adi Shankara revived the shrine and converted it to a Hindu temple.[7][10] The architecture of the temple resembling that of a Buddhist vihara (temple) and the brightly painted facade which is atypical of Buddhist temples leads to the argument.[2] Other accounts relate that it was originally established as a pilgrimage site by Adi Shankara in the ninth century. It is believed that Shankara resided in the place for six years from 814 to 820 CE. He resided six months in Badrinath and the rest of the year in Kedarnath. Hindu followers assert that he discovered the deity of Badrinath in the Alaknanda River and enshrined it in a cave near the Tapt Kund hot springs.[8][11] A traditional story asserts that Adi Shankara expelled all the Buddhists in the region with the help of the Parmar ruler king Kanak Pal. The hereditary successors of the king governed the temple and endowed villages to meet its expenses. The income from a set of villages on the route to the temple was used to feed and accommodate pilgrims. The Parmar rulers held the title "Bolanda Badrinath", meaning speaking Badrinath. They had other titles, including Shri 108 Basdrishcharyaparayan Garharaj Mahimahendra, Dharmabibhab, and Dharamarakshak Sigamani.[12]
The throne of Badrinath was named after the presiding deity; the king enjoyed ritual obeisance by the devotees before proceeding to the shrine. The practice was continued until the late 19th century.[12] During the 16th century, the King of Garhwal moved the murti to the present temple.[8] When the state of Garhwal was divided, the Badrinath temple came under British rule but the king of Garhwal continued as the chairman of the management committee. The selection of priest is done after consultation between Garhwal and Travancore royal families.[12]

Doleshwor Mahadeva (Nepali: डोलेश्वर महादेव) is a Hindu Temple of Lord Shiva located in Suryabinayak, south eastern part of Bhaktapur District, Nepal, and is believed to be the head part of Kedarnath temple located in Uttarakhand, India.

The Hindu activist Bharat Jangam had been researching and claiming that Doleshwar Mahadev is the head part of Kedarnath based on the surprising links between Kedarnath and Doleshwor. The Sculptures of Shive found in both shrines are 4,000 years old. Even a stone scripture found in Doleshwor was written in Sanskrit and Old Nepalese. The priests in both shrines are selected from India's southern states of Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Kerala and Tamil Nadu. Both priests affix the word ‘ling’ after their names to convey their proximity to the god as his worshipper and both temples have a cluster of five Shiva shrines. The main deity of both priests is Birbhadra, a companion of Shiva, according to Hindu scriptures.

Muktinath Temple, a sacred site for both Hindus and Buddhists, is located in the Mustang district of Nepal at an altitude of 3,710 meters in the Himalayan range. Known as "Mukti Kshetra," meaning "place of liberation," it is a revered pilgrimage destination attracting devotees from Nepal, India, and beyond. The temple is dedicated to Lord Vishnu in Hindu tradition and Avalokiteshvara in Buddhist belief, symbolizing a unique confluence of religious harmony.

The temple’s architecture is modest yet spiritually significant, with a pagoda-style structure surrounded by breathtaking landscapes of the Annapurna mountain range. A key feature of Muktinath is the 108 sacred water spouts shaped like bulls’ heads, known as "Muktidhara." Pilgrims bathe under these spouts, believing it cleanses them of sins. Adjacent to the temple is the eternal flame, or "Jwala Mai," fueled by natural gas, a phenomenon held sacred by both faiths.

Accessible via a challenging trek or helicopter ride, the journey to Muktinath is considered a part of the pilgrimage. The area is also rich in cultural significance, with monasteries, prayer wheels, and stone-carved deities adding to its spiritual aura. The nearby Kali Gandaki River is renowned for Shaligram stones, considered manifestations of Lord Vishnu. The temple operates year-round, though the peak season is from March to October.

The **Kaal Bhairav** statue, located within **Kathmandu Durbar Square** (Hanuman Dhoka), is one of the most revered and iconic representations of the fierce manifestation of Lord Shiva. This enormous stone idol of Kaal Bhairav stands as a symbol of justice and power in Nepalese culture.

Here are some key details about **Kaal Bhairav** in Kathmandu:

1. **Depiction**: Kaal Bhairav is depicted as a fearsome form of Lord Shiva, with a wrathful expression, holding a severed head in one hand and weapons in others. He is often surrounded by snakes, skulls, and other symbolic elements representing death and destruction. This fierce form is believed to protect the righteous and punish wrongdoers.

2. **Historical and Religious Significance**: The Kaal Bhairav idol is said to date back to the 12th century, although some believe it may have been created even earlier. It holds deep religious importance in both Hinduism and local traditions, where Kaal Bhairav is worshipped as the protector of the Kathmandu Valley.

3. **Role in Justice**: In the past, the statue played a role in the legal system. People who were accused of crimes would be brought before the Kaal Bhairav idol to swear oaths of innocence. It was believed that those who lied would face immediate divine punishment.

4. **Location**: The statue is situated in an open courtyard of **Hanuman Dhoka Durbar Square**, which is itself a historically significant palace complex. The Kaal Bhairav statue is easily recognizable due to its massive size (approximately 12 feet tall) and striking appearance.

5. **Cultural Importance**: Locals and visitors alike pay their respects to Kaal Bhairav, offering flowers, vermillion powder, and other traditional offerings. The site remains an important place of worship, particularly during festivals.

The **Kaal Bhairav** statue continues to draw both devotees and tourists, serving as a reminder of the deep spiritual and historical heritage embedded within Kathmandu Durbar Square.

Kumari Ghar, also known as the House of the Living Goddess, is a small but significant palace located in Kathmandu Durbar Square, Nepal. This ornate, three-story structure is the residence of the Kumari, a young girl believed to be the living embodiment of the Hindu goddess Taleju. The tradition of the Kumari, a centuries-old practice, is deeply rooted in Nepalese culture, where the chosen girl, usually from the Newar Shakya caste, is worshipped as a goddess until she reaches puberty.

The Kumari Ghar itself is a striking example of traditional Newari architecture, with its intricately carved wooden windows and doors, and a richly decorated courtyard. The building was constructed in 1757 by King Jaya Prakash Malla and has since been the residence of the Kumari. The most famous of the windows is the one from which the Kumari occasionally appears to give blessings to visitors and devotees, a rare and sacred moment for those who witness it.

While the interior of Kumari Ghar is not accessible to the public, the exterior and the courtyard can be viewed by visitors. The living goddess is rarely seen, except during special religious festivals, such as Indra Jatra, when she is carried through the streets in a ceremonial procession. Despite the fascinating cultural significance of the Kumari Ghar, some visitors might find the experience less engaging due to the restricted access and the heavily touristic atmosphere around the Durbar Square area. Nonetheless, Kumari Ghar remains a unique and culturally rich site that offers a glimpse into one of Nepal's most intriguing traditions.

In Nepal, a Kumari is a prepubescent girl selected from the Shakya clan of the Nepalese Newari Buddhist community. The Kumari is also revered and worshiped by some of the country's Hindus. While there are several Kumaris throughout Nepal, with some cities having several, the best known is the Royal Kumari of Kathmandu, and she lives in the Kumari Ghar, a palace in the center of the city. The selection process for her is especially rigorous. As of 2023, the Royal Kumari of Kathmandu is Trishna Shakya, aged five, installed in September 2017. Unika Bajracharya, selected in April 2014 as the Kumari of Patan, is the second most important living goddess.
In Kathmandu Valley, this is a particularly prevalent practice. It is believed to be the incarnation of Taleju, a manifestation of the goddess Durga.
When her first menstruation begins, it is believed that the deity vacates her body. Serious illness or a major loss of blood from an injury also causes loss of deity.

The Kumari, known as the living goddess of Nepal, is revered as the incarnation of the Hindu goddess Durga or the Buddhist goddess Vajradevi. This unique tradition is deeply woven into the cultural fabric of Kathmandu Valley.

Key facts about the Kumari:

Selection: The Kumari is chosen from the Newar community, the indigenous people of the valley.
Life: She leads a secluded life, rarely seen in public and is not allowed to smile or live a typical childhood.
Festivals: The Kumari appears during important festivals, where she is worshipped by both Hindus and Buddhists

Bhaleshwar Mahadev Temple on Chandragiri Hill

Located in the Bagmati Province, straddling the districts of Kathmandu and Makwanpur, the Bhaleshwar Mahadev Temple on Chandragiri Hill is a remarkable destination that combines spiritual reverence, natural beauty, and recreational opportunities. Situated at an elevation of 2,551 meters (8,369 feet) above sea level, the temple offers an exceptional viewpoint over the Kathmandu Valley, making it an ideal spot for both sunrise and sunset views.

Scenic Views and Spiritual Significance

One of the most captivating aspects of visiting the Bhaleshwar Mahadev Temple is the awe-inspiring panoramic view of the Kathmandu Valley. The temple’s elevated position provides an unobstructed vista, allowing visitors to take in the sprawling urban landscape below, framed by the majestic Himalayan mountains. Sunrise and sunset are particularly magical times to visit, as the sky transforms into a canvas of vibrant colors, casting a serene glow over the valley and enhancing the spiritual ambiance of the temple.

The Bhaleshwar Mahadev Temple itself is a beautiful and sacred site dedicated to Lord Shiva. It attracts numerous devotees who come to offer prayers and seek blessings. The temple’s architecture, combined with the tranquil surroundings, creates a peaceful environment perfect for meditation and reflection. The spiritual energy of the place, coupled with the natural beauty, makes it a must-visit for those seeking both solace and inspiration.

Adventure and Recreation

Beyond its spiritual and scenic appeal, Chandragiri Hill offers a range of adventurous activities that cater to thrill-seekers. The zipline and cycling paths provide an adrenaline rush against the backdrop of stunning natural scenery. The zipline experience, in particular, offers a unique way to appreciate the landscape, soaring above the treetops with a bird’s-eye view of the surroundings.

For families and individuals looking for more leisurely pursuits, Chandragiri Hill does not disappoint. The area features well-maintained playgrounds and parks that are perfect for children, ensuring they have a fun and engaging experience. Adults can also enjoy these spaces, whether for a relaxing stroll or a picnic. Additionally, horse riding is available, offering a delightful way to explore the hill’s trails and enjoy the fresh mountain air.

Dining and Amenities

After a day of exploration and spiritual enrichment, visitors can enjoy a variety of dining options on Chandragiri Hill. The hilltop is home to several good restaurants that cater to diverse culinary preferences, offering both vegetarian and non-vegetarian cuisine. These establishments provide a comfortable place to rest and refuel while enjoying delicious meals with stunning views as a backdrop.

Conclusion

Bhaleshwar Mahadev Temple on Chandragiri Hill is an exceptional destination that offers a unique blend of spirituality, adventure, and leisure. Its prime location in the Bagmati Province, with easy access from both Kathmandu and Makwanpur, makes it a convenient getaway for locals and tourists alike. Whether you are drawn by the spiritual allure of the temple, the breathtaking views of the Kathmandu Valley, the thrilling adventure activities, or the family-friendly amenities, Chandragiri Hill promises a memorable experience for visitors of all ages.

The Chandragiri Hils are quite significant from a historical standpoint. It was from these hills that King Prithivi Narayan Shah caught the first glimpse of a much scenic and prosperous Kathmandu valley, which in fact instilled in the king's mind an idea of annexing the valley into his kingdom According to folklore, Prithivi Narayan Shah is beleved to have amassed spiritual powers for unification process after undergoing rigorous meditation or 'sadhana' at these very hilis. The Gorkhali king disguised himself while ascending the hills in order to avoid being recognized by the Malla Kings of Kathmandu in his Divine Preaching (Divyopades), it has been mentioned that King Prithivi Narayan was determined to first annex and then make Kathmandu the capital of unified Nepal. He apparently first saw the valley while on his way back to his kingdom in Gorkha from his in-law's realm in Makwanpur According to Historian Prof. Dr. Dinesh Raj Panta, astrologers Bhanu Aryal and Kulananda Dhakal who accompanied the king during that trip had made a prediction that their king's wish to takeover Kathmandu would definitely come true. As per popular belief, pleased with his perseverance and Sadhana, it was Bhaleshwara Mahadev that granted King Prithivi Narayan Shah his wishes

Place: Doleshwor Mahadeva, the head of the Kedarnath
Text:
Doleshwor Mahadeva (Nepali: डोलेश्वर महादेव) is a Hindu Temple of Lord Shiva located in Suryabinayak, south eastern part of Bhaktapur District, Nepal, and is believed to be the head part of Kedarnath temple located in Uttarakhand, India.

The Hindu activist Bharat Jangam had been researching and claiming that Doleshwar Mahadev is the head part of Kedarnath based on the surprising links between Kedarnath and Doleshwor. The Sculptures of Shive found in both shrines are 4,000 years old. Even a stone scripture found in Doleshwor was written in Sanskrit and Old Nepalese. The priests in both shrines are selected from India's southern states of Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Kerala and Tamil Nadu. Both priests affix the word ‘ling’ after their names to convey their proximity to the god as his worshipper and both temples have a cluster of five Shiva shrines. The main deity of both priests is Birbhadra, a companion of Shiva, according to Hindu scriptures.

It is situated in Suryabinayak, Bhaktapur District in Nepal, about 20 km from Kathmandu. The statue is 143 feet in height and was made using copper, zinc, concrete, and steel

Designed to resemble images of the Hindu god, Shiva, and seen as a marvel of Nepalese engineering, the statue's construction began in 2003 and was completed in 2011. It was constructed mainly by Kamal Jain and "Hilltake", a company established in Nepal in 1992 which deals with products such as water tanks.

Sagarmatha National Park, located in northeastern Nepal, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and home to some of the world's highest peaks, including the iconic Mount Everest. Encompassing an area of 1,148 square kilometers, the park boasts breathtaking landscapes that range from deep valleys to towering mountain peaks, including Lhotse, Cho Oyu, and Nuptse. The park is a haven for biodiversity, featuring rare and endangered species such as the elusive red panda and the Himalayan tahr. Sagarmatha, meaning "forehead of the sky" in Nepali, is a testament to the rich cultural tapestry of the region, with several Sherpa villages dotting the landscape. Namche Bazaar, a bustling market town within the park, serves as a gateway to Everest Base Camp and is a hub for trekkers and mountaineers embarking on their journey to the world's highest summit. The park is not only a trekker's paradise but also a site of immense ecological and cultural significance, showcasing the delicate balance between nature and human civilization in the heart of the Himalayas.

The Birthplace of Gautama Buddha in Lumbini, Nepal, is one of the most serene and spiritually enriching places in the world. Surrounding the temple, the lush gardens and monastic zones, home to monasteries built by various Buddhist nations, add a unique cultural richness. Each monastery reflects the architecture and spirituality of its country, creating a global tapestry of Buddhism in one place.

The Eternal Peace Flame and the World Peace Pagoda further amplify the message of harmony and unity, reminding visitors of Buddha’s timeless teachings. Walking along the peaceful canals or meditating under the Bodhi trees is a surreal experience that leaves you with a sense of inner calm and gratitude.

Lumbini is not just a destination; it is a journey into self-discovery and mindfulness. It’s a place where you feel deeply connected to humanity, a reminder of the potential for peace within and around us. Truly, this UNESCO World Heritage Site is one of the most remarkable places on Earth, and it leaves every visitor inspired and humbled. A visit here is not just a trip; it’s a transformative experience.

Place: Lumbini, the Birthplace of the Lord Buddha
Text:
The Birthplace of Gautam Buddha, located in Lumbini, Nepal, is one of the most sacred and revered pilgrimage sites in the world. This UNESCO World Heritage Site holds immense historical, spiritual, and cultural significance, making it a must-visit destination for those interested in Buddhism, history, and serene landscapes.

Lumbini is renowned as the birthplace of Siddhartha Gautama, who later became known as Buddha, the founder of Buddhism. According to historical and religious accounts, Buddha was born here in the 6th century BCE. The site offers a profound and contemplative experience, with its rich spiritual ambiance and well-preserved archaeological and religious monuments.

The primary attraction at Lumbini is the Maya Devi Temple, which marks the exact spot where Queen Maya Devi is believed to have given birth to Buddha. This ancient temple, adorned with intricate carvings and artwork, is a focal point of pilgrimage and worship. The temple’s serene environment, combined with its historical significance, provides a deep sense of connection to Buddhist heritage.

Adjacent to the Maya Devi Temple is the Sacred Garden, a lush and peaceful area that includes the sacred Bodhi Tree, where it is said that Buddha’s mother, Queen Maya, experienced a divine vision before his birth. The garden offers a tranquil space for meditation and reflection, surrounded by beautifully maintained pathways and gardens.

The Lumbini Archaeological Museum is another important site within the complex. It houses a vast collection of artifacts, sculptures, and inscriptions related to Buddha’s life and the early years of Buddhism. The museum provides valuable insights into the historical and cultural context of the region, making it a worthwhile visit for anyone interested in deepening their understanding of Buddhist history.

In addition to the Maya Devi Temple and the Archaeological Museum, Lumbini features several monasteries and stupas built by various Buddhist countries. Each monastery reflects the architectural styles and cultural influences of its respective nation, creating a diverse and enriching experience for visitors. The monasteries offer a glimpse into different Buddhist traditions and practices, fostering a sense of international unity and spiritual harmony.

The peaceful ambiance of Lumbini is enhanced by its well-planned layout and the surrounding natural beauty. The site is dotted with serene ponds, gardens, and trees, providing a perfect backdrop for contemplation and relaxation. The gentle sounds of nature and the absence of commercial hustle contribute to an atmosphere of tranquility and spiritual renewal.

Visiting Lumbini is not only a journey to a historical and religious landmark but also an opportunity to experience a profound sense of peace and reflection. The site’s significance as Buddha’s birthplace makes it a place of pilgrimage and reverence for Buddhists from around the world. At the same time, it offers a universal message of peace, compassion, and enlightenment that resonates with people of all backgrounds.

For those traveling to Lumbini, the nearby town offers various accommodations, dining options, and local attractions. The local community is welcoming and hospitable, enhancing the overall experience of visiting this sacred site. Whether you are a devout Buddhist, a history enthusiast, or simply seeking a peaceful retreat, Lumbini provides a unique and enriching experience that will leave a lasting impression.

In conclusion, the Birthplace of Gautam Buddha in Lumbini is a remarkable destination that combines historical significance, spiritual depth, and natural beauty. Its sacred sites, diverse monasteries, and serene environment make it a compelling place to visit, offering both historical insights and spiritual renewal. Highly recommended for anyone seeking a meaningful and tranquil experience in one of the world’s most revered locations.
